Almost no roads in sight, just vegetation, it's a nice place to spend the evening, or even an afternoon. The food and drink are, to me, are more than satisfactory. I love their house salad, a mixed green salad livened up by blueberries, sunflower seeds, and a delicious pomegranate dressing. Very addictive. I also thoroughly enjoy their mud crab pasta. While I usually don't order crab because I'm lazy to work for my food, the flavour of the crab blends very well with the sauce, and I order it almost every time I go. They have a great mushroom soup, though I forget exactly what they call it, and an excellent selection of cocktails. Their truffle fries are also a big hit, though the lactose intolerant should be aware that theirs come served with cheese. When I first heard of PS.Cafe though, it was for their cakes and desserts. The Chocolate Blackout is IMMENSE, and I refuse to believe anyone can finish it alone. Their puddings are really good, though I found their key lime pie just 'okay'. Overall it's a little pricey to be a regular fixture on my weekly schedule, but a great place to head to when you want to meet up with friends you haven't seen in forever. It can be a little noisy on Friday and Saturday nights though, so if you're hoping for long intense conversations... it's not always ideal.

I hate to do this but I need to get this off my chest.  Yesterday after a wonderful brunch of quiche and sangria I was leaving this Dempsey establishment and admiring the bread selection. At the moment of almost grabbing the ash boule a rat crawled out from the bread, my friends and I screamed and ran from the restaurant. I hope they threw away the bread.  Either way I will never eat there again.And thats too bad becuase I loved that restaurant. I fantasized about moving the restaurant out and living in the beautiful glass and concrete structure. I think their sangrias are some of the best breakfast drinks around. I am a huge fan of the food and decor. But a rat killed it for me.

This was one of my favorite places to do brunch when I lived in Singapore. The ambiance was very serene minus the flies lol. You definitely want to sit outdoors if the weather is nice. The best alcoholic drinks were the White Bouquet Sangria and the Rose and Berries Sangria. They were infused with both flowers and fruit...heavenI normally order the pancakes which are pretty good.  The menu can be a bit pricey but so is everything else in Singapore :)

user_location: Central Business District, New Orleans, LA
comment: Great atmosphere of old Singapore.  Need reservations otherwise long wait. Nice variety of food. French fries areoverrated and they need to change the oil. Burgers excellent. No key lime pie today. Salad with blueberries and pomegranate seeds excellent. Service fair. Price reasonable.  Wait staff disorganized and need training.

A good environment to hang out with friends and chat. The drinks are a little overpriced but not unreasonable, especially when you consider its in the Dempsey area; everything is pricier there.We had four drinks and the truffle fries, which were a slight disappointment to me. These are your typical frozen shoestring French fries, and while they did do the best they could with it, there's a lot of room of improvement in improving the quality of the potatoes they are frying with.Drinks were pretty standard, with a few specialty cocktails.

A beautiful cafe in the jungles atop Dempsey Hill. A great place to enjoy a romantic brunch in lush jungles and unwind with a nice cocktails. Serving sizes are American sized and the breakfast is very delicious. The tea is amazing too. The only down side is the price. Quite pricey for something you can purchase at Denny's for half the price. But ita Singapore so it's expected.

Okay, let's just get it out of the way: everything on the brunch menu is yummy. Ev-ar-ee-thing. So, don't fuss over what to order, unless you're super picky. It's all good, yo. Fer realz.All the P.S. Cafe outlets are pretty solid when it comes to food quality, I've found. What they offer in terms of locations, though, is atmosphere and ambiance. THIS spot has the most relaxing brunch views of them all. The outdoor area opens up onto grass -- and lots of it. Bring the kids and the pram, let them run around while you sip your soy latte (soy! yay!) and read the paper as you tuck into some waffles. COME EARLY as it's clearly no secret that this is a popular place for brunchin.' You will have to wait unless you get here when they open, which is at 10am. But you won't regret it. You could hang onto that table all afternoon iffin ya wanna. My only complaint (and hence the 4 stars instead of 5) is that the service is patchy. I should not have to ask you to top up my water. I also should not have to flail my arms wildly on the patio to get your attention. And I should not have to wait 15 minutes for you to bring my bill, only to discover that you've brought the wrong bill, and then worry that you don't know what we ordered in the first place. Get those last bits together, Harding, and we'll be on our way to 5-star brunch paradise.

It's really easy to get sick of this place if you eat more than a couple times. The atmosphere is nice and location is good however menu never changes. Their choices are bland and there are not very many options.

Great place for a lazy Sunday afternoon. Come with friends order cocktails (basil lemon mojito, yum!) and truffle fries and enjoy the relaxed atmosphere.The crowd is very mixed with some families, couples, groups of friends a handful of hipsters, Westerners and locals.It's one of my favorite restaurants at Dempsey Hill because it's more secluded than the others and with all the green around you, you barely feel like you're still in bustling Singapore.

Difficult to find, entrance dark and needs cleaning, not welcoming, place needs to be refurbished, very noisy with loud music, difficult to have a conversation, main course came with cold mash potato and vegetables, cod was good but accompanied salad was too small, service was average but they still charged for it

Tasty Western foods and sweet sinful desserts! This food joint offers diners a selection of tasty Western foods and sweet sinful desserts. On entering the restaurant, The zinc roof, large yellow round lamps, lounge music and beautiful view gives the restaurant a unique rustic feel, while still providing a relaxing and air-conditioned environment for patrons to dine comfortably.Food - Portion of food was decent, however, price is a bit on the high side. Chicken Rossa Penne- This pasta dish offers an interesting and rich mix of delicious ingredients (chicken, bacon, mushrooms) served in creamy tomato sauce. PS. Fish & Chips - we had better fish & chips elsewhere. However, the fish fillets and fries were still delicious enough for our palatesBBQ Ribs- succulent and juicy pork ribs are covered in a thick layer of barbeque blackcurrant sauce, wonderfully tender and moist!PS.Profiteroles - sinful dessert that was pretty normal, cream puffs covered in chocolate sauce and embellished with almond flakes.Truffle Shoestring Fries - Juicy fries are endowed with truffle oil, and topped off with just a tad of grated Parmesan cheese and parsley.Overall, soft lighting, relaxing music, unimpeded view of the greenery, and rustic restaurant décor make this the perfect place for hanging out with friends and loved ones. The restaurant also serves nice food!Check out our full review and photos at eatandtravelwithus.com/2…

I do a lot of lunches here both for business and pleasure. It's pricey given it's casual setting. It would even raise a few eyebrows in Beverly Hills for the audacity of the brunch menu prices but ... welcome to Singapore! If it's even remotely decent western food it's going to be priced like truffle oil. I usually do soup and/or salad and have to say the lunch menu has never let me down. This is on par with the cafes I used to grab lunch in San Francisco. I also get the most consistently good soy lattes here. Dinner time is a little more dressy. It's a nice spot to come for a good cocktail and a nice meal out on the patio. Brunches are a zoo. Seriously, it's like Disneyland on New Years if you come on a Sunday. The brunch food is pretty good though I've occasionally had some very sketchy [read: raw whites] eggs. Now this happens a lot around town so even in high end places I've kinda given up on my old friend eggs benny. Desserts are to die for. The carrot cake is my current crush but I also had a brief entanglement with the ginger toffee cake that could have got serious. Don't miss dessert even if you have to take it to-go.

This outlet, while quaintly surrounded by the greenery, is not recommended if you don't drive - well you can take a cab there but will have to call for a cab when you're done. Unless you don't mind the walk through dempsey down to holland road to take the bus. It's a really romantic atmosphere if you're walking in here in the evening, the pathway is lined with candles before you enter the bustling cafe. It's usually full of people, you'd be lucky to get a table on weekends without making a reservation. I've been here for dinner once, I found the food too average for the price (or maybe I didn't order the right stuff). Had the chicken parmiggiano and truffle fries. The chicken was a little bland and the fries, while served in a generously hefty portion, significantly lacked the truffle flavour, it almost feels like they forgot the truffle somehow. I like the touch of parmesan cheese on top but could do with more cheese!I've also been here for a tea break. My friend and I were on a pie hunt and PS cafe have some really good pies. Their display of desserts will have you salivating! I had the key lime pie while my friend had the chocolate walnut pie. The key lime pie was an absolute delight of citrus burst in your mouth, so refreshingly good! I just didn't like whip cream on top of it that had some coconut sprinkles, I'll be sure to tell them to skip that the next time I order it, the pie is fine on its own. The walnut pie was really rich, we couldn't finish it!Final verdict: Come here for a nice date night or if you live nearby otherwise there are other more accessible PS Cafes in town but definitely DO NOT miss out on the key lime pie! Oh but not all outlets serve the key lime pie though, the one at Ann Siang for one, doesn't serve the key lime.
Whoever has a big sweet tooth will appreciate the choices of dessert ....go for the cakes!! The slices are massive! It's nice to sit outside on a cool evening...can get crowded on a weekend

Good food for those looking for a change from the usual SG fare. We started with the Truffle Fries-which were a huge serving and very tasty. Definitely enough for 4 people. It was a bit much for 2. I had Flamed Shrimp Torteglini and my friend had the Miso Cod. Both were very good.Prices were high, but overall a nice place for dinner. Being in Dempsey, it provided a nice area to walk afterwards, but definitely not MRT/Bus friendly.

PS Cafe is no stranger to the cafe market in Singapore. One of the first eateries to make Dempsey hip, it is vastly different to its other branches in Orchard. This one is tucked away amidst verdant greenery and with ceiling-to-floor glass windows, the view and light streaming in doesn't get better.Great for weekend brunch, or afternoon tea, or dinner, there really isn't a bad time to come. The menu has favorites such as a big breakfast, truffle fries, a hearty mushroom soup and decadent desserts. Prices are slightly verging on overpriced for a place people come for brunch or dessert but you're pretty much paying for the ambience and the cool yuppie looks other yuppies give you.

Great brunch place, even though it's overpriced. Also super long wait time during weekend peak brunch time. but the location is lovely with seating outside with greenery. The coffee and pastries are good as well as the breakfast options.

I really really like this spot! I had brunch here with some friends and I got the blue cheese quiche drizzled lightly with some balsamic vinaigrette type of sauce and I enjoyed every single bite of it! I've also been here for dessert and I've tried the key lime pie (AMAZING), pecan pie, and a cheesecake. All were great but the key lime definitely stood out!overall - great place to just chill, grab a drink, enjoy food and friends =)

The PS Café in Dempsey Hill is my favorite branch of the restaurant. Its set amidst lush greenery and is set up like a greenhouse. Chose to sit inside, but I prefer sitting outside facing nature. The food is a bit pricey here, but you pay for the ambience as well. Ive tried a lot of food here and its mostly Western with a bit of fusion Asian thrown in. Their fish and chips are good, as are their truffle fries and salads. They have interesting drinks and cocktails and my favorite to get is the lime and mint soda--kind of like a non alcoholic mojito. Definitely come here for the desserts. The apple crumble is pretty good and served with vanilla ice cream. A nice place to go for brunch on the weekends.

Out of all the outlets that P.S. Cafe has around Singapore, the branch at Dempsey has got to be my favourite. The restaurant is nestled in the greenery of Dempsey, and has an alfresco dining area which is really pleasant to sit at in the afternoons. Food, as with all the P.S. Cafe restaurants, is decent - though some might call it overpriced. Come for the desserts which are massive, and good enough to share with 2 other people. Also come to people watch. The crowd at this branch tends to be trendier and better looking than the other branches. Side note though: this branch gets massively overpacked over the weekends, so reservations are recommended.

Tucked away in the greener part of Dempsey Hill is the fantastic place! High ceilings, funky straight forward decor makes this cafe one of the more charming of its style in Singapore.  The large menu features a great selection of comfort food items all for under $30.  Service is always very warm and friendly, in fact one of the friendliest bunch of floor staff in Singapore. PS Café have really recreated that funky comforting café vibe that I miss from places back in Sydney and Melbourne.  The selection of cakes and desserts are not to be missed, regardless of if you have room for dessert.Weather its been a Monday night after work or a lazy brunch, every time I've set foot in this place its packed. Though when you have a restaurant in a fantastic location, that provides the full package in terms of service, food and ambience its not hard to see why its so busy

When I go to restaurants, I'm always keen on the Specials.  So I have chosen their Specials a couple of time and they are a miss.  We went there sometime Christmas and it was just a couple of ham slices piled up with a very salty sauce.  We all had the same thing and they came looking different from one another with different serving sizes.So lesson learned -- stick to their basics -- Ceasar Salad, Truffle Fries, Eggs Benedict...Service also becomes bad when they are full -- so avoid weekends!

Love, love, love this place. The glass house, the green surrounding, the truffle fries, the cakes - it's one of the must go places in my opinion and I recommend it to all of my friends who visit Singapore. Prices are reasonable for the ambience and quality.
Service is phenomenal. Food was delicious. I ordered pizza here and was very pleased. Truffle fries were on point. The desserts are to die for. Highly recommended.

Truffle fries and deserts my dudes. That's what matter at this place. The entrees and appetizers I've had here have been satisfying but not exactly memorable. However the milkshakes, pastries, and fries I've had here have all been fantastic. Order their truffle fries and a milk shake for a classed up version of the old frosty and fries combo at Wendy's. Beware though, it's kind of expensive for what you get - but it's Singapore, everything is expensive.

I tried PS cafe with a friend on the recommendation of her coworkers. The place was gorgeous and we were able to sit outside, probably because we got there on a Sunday just before 11am. Of course we had to order the truffle fries based on the recommendations. I had the eggs benedict and my friend had the pesto pasta. I must admit her pesto looked really good, but my benedict was everything I was looking for as well. The truffle fries more than lived up to expectations. I definitely recommend this place and hope to return!

The service is horrible.  Waited for drinks, silverware and water.  Not once did our waitress check on us to see if our food was good, when serving, they just drop off the food and don't comment on what the dish is.  The drinks are far from good (i.e. Mixed or gin infused spirits). The food is just average.  Nice location.
My favorite place for desserts! The queue can be quite long and sometimes the waiters are so busy! But overall great place and good food!
Food was good but can improve in the service aspect. We were not attended to as fast as normal and it took a long time to process the credit card for payment.

A pricey establishment indeed but set a in quieter part of Dempsey facing lush greenery, probably best experienced when you seat alfresco. Choose between regular tables or low couches if you're intending to kick  back and do some reading. This is one of the first places in Singapore where I tried the Sticky Date Pudding and it was pretty good. Careful with the caramel or it could get a little too sweet. The general standard of food is good with your typical modern bistro spread with the only factor being ridiculous pricing. Other than that, people do indeed come for the environment. With an urbanized landscape like ours, how often do you get to sit facing a mini forest and enjoy your cuppa.

This is my favourite chain of roast duck in Singapore. I love the shi quan ya. Another favourite dish of mine is the fish maw soup.New dishes are introduced regularly. I just tried out the claypot beehoon with prawns and frog legs. The beehoon could be cooked longer in the stock because the stock is flavorful, but the beehoon is a bit plain.Tofu with sponge gourd, crab meat and black fungus is ok ok. Crab meat is almost non existence.Very fast service and dishes come fast in the few branches I go to.

This is still my favorite Dian Xiao Er outlet. I must say it totally changed my opinion of duck. I never really like duck meat as it is always chewy and gamey to me, but when it is braised or doused with the herbal sauce as in Dian Xiao Er, the duck meat becomes so much tenderer and full of sweet herbal flavor. The downside of this outlet is they will only seat you when your entire party is there. But generally it is pretty quick to get a table even when there is a long line. Food is served promptly and the turnover of tables is fast. The food is just so good. I like the duck in all the various herbal sauces. The fish slices, dong po pork (melts in your mouth), baby kailan with lime and salted fish (crunchy and tart), mongolian spare ribs, braised mushrooms with broccoli and tofu are all delicious. I am not a big fan of the marmite chicken though many others like it. They have set menus from 2 persons, besides ala carte dishes. They also have a duck portion with rice for one person which is great for days you happen to be alone and is in the mood for duck. You also get a nice view of Sentosa or the water if you sit in the outside area. Yelp Feb 2014 Challenge: 17/28
Ducks! Ducks! Ducks!!!Their ducks sends me to heaven. Definitely the best in Singapore!
It's contemporary-rustic chinese food at its best. Very reasonably priced chinese food, efficient service, good variety of dishes, including mongolian lamb, XO fried rice etc.

address: Alexandra Retail Centre, 460 Alexandra Road #02-19 Singapore 119963 Singapore
comment: Sugar 'N Spice sounds more like a popgroup or stripbar, therefore most people refer to this restaurant as "The Vietnamese place at ARC". Interestingly enough this place actually wants to be Fusion. But besides the spaghetti and chicken chop, it is more Vietnamese than anything. Sometimes I just crave for a good Vietnamese beef bisque noodle soup and this Vietnamese place at ARC never lets me down. The lunchtime sets are very reasonable and  allows you a choice of appetizer, main course and a dessert. All of them good quality, rich and fresh flavours. Yummy!

address: Block 125 Bukit Merah Lane 1 Singapore 150125 Singapore
comment: My parents work across the street from this small "hawker center zi cha" stall, and I've seen it change over the years. It started out being absolutely amazing and my brother and I would meet our parents over at the stall to have a quick and simple, and CHEAP dinner. Apparently since I've left to pursue life in a different couple of continents, the main owner had passed away after becoming really ill. He had to sell the stall away to someone that really brought the place down. My parents even stopped their patronage. About a year ago, the former owner's brother took over the stall and has brought it back to greatness. If you're visiting Queensway Shopping Centre, or Ikea, this is the place to go for a good meal. The fried beef kway teow is truly one of the best in the business, and has a much more local flavour than anything else I've had (Hong Kong style included), and the fish slice kway teow with bean sprouts is a definite staple for the place. I don't think their shrimp paste fried chicken (har cheong gai) has returned to former glory, but it's definitely good in the books.The location is still a little out of the way, but it's worth it if you drive or don't mind a trek off the beaten path.

rest_name: Tong Fong Fatt Hainanese Boneless Chicken Rice
address: ABC Brickworks Food Centre, #01-32 6 Jalan Bukit Merah Singapore 150006 Singapore
comment: My favourite food court near Alexander Road. Nothing to add - just enjoy it!  A perfect taste of Asian food. Your tongue will love it

rest_name: Tong Fong Fatt Hainanese Boneless Chicken Rice
address: ABC Brickworks Food Centre, #01-32 6 Jalan Bukit Merah Singapore 150006 Singapore
comment: Above average chicken rice, meat is always tender, even when they serve you with breast meat.My only gripe is everything is a little too oily, and salty.The rice is fragrant but really quite oily, and the sauce poured over the meat is too salty, I tend to add spoons of soup (also oily) to restore some balance to the taste. They also fall a little short in the chili department (too watery and believe it or not, salty too) but it'll do.Good enough and better than most out there.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Pl #01-35/36 Galaxis Building Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: A truly friendly, healthy and gentle sanctuary in a rather spacious but quiet Fusionopolis.  My Daughter is a strict vegetarian but manages to find great places to eat sans meat, poultry, fish and dairy.  The young man who greeted us had a mild speech impediment.  We had no reservation. He mumbled then sort of waved us to a table.  When I sat down the first thing I noticed on the menu was that 40% of their staff are special needs. It asked for our patience and understanding.The menu was set up so that you scan with a mobile phone to order.  Not a lot of staff work involved other than serving.  But the staff smiled and said "Please come back" when we finished.The food was exceptional, tasty, and well-prepared.   The dumplings were better than any I have had with meat or pork. The spicy soup went really well with brown rice.  The salad was very fresh with an amazing dressing. The place was full but not noisy. The ambience and food put us in a great mood.My compliments to everyone there for delivering a very positive experience and adhering to noble, commendable principals.My only complaint was that no alcohol is served (no soju, maguli or Cass beer) but with such healthy, nutritious fare it makes perfect sense.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Pl #01-35/36 Galaxis Building Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: Great food and service. Nice calm and a great weekend brunch spot to unwind and have some great Korean vegetation comfort food.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Pl #01-35/36 Galaxis Building Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: Vegetarian Korean in Fusionopolis - good food. Would recommend the Kimchi pancake and the army stew. Doesn't feel like I'm missing out from good Korean food by having vegetarian. Reasonable pricing. Quite popular with the working crowd so would recommend making a reservation

address: 1 Fusionopolis Pl #01-35/36 Galaxis Building Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: Delicious vegetarian Korean food. Some foods do come with dairy, so ask before ordering. Loved their pancakes and daboki! Appreciated it not being too spicy like most Korean restaurants.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Pl #01-35/36 Galaxis Building Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: I love their bulgogi - perfect noodles, and their dumplings - crispy outside, steamy inside, with a finely balanced dipping sauce. The people who work there are lovely, and food comes out of the kitchen fast. Thank you, Daewha!!

address: 1 Maritime Square #01-99/100, HarbourFront Centre Singapore 099253 Singapore
comment: Before coming here, I researched their menu and decided to go for Chef's Bibim Guksoo (Signature pork bulgogi fried noodles).Wasn't as crowded during lunch time on a weekday and was ushered to the seat pretty quickly. While the server handed me the menu, I told him what I wanted so they could prepare the dish but also asked him to hold on to the drink.Food served within 5 minutes. The servers were very fast in punching the item on the computers and serving it. The ambience of this location is also pretty good - very airy and the use of light colored furniture in an open space dining place made it more inviting. For the food, I love it! The noodles are medium soft and chewy. The egg is sweet, the seaweeds gave an extra crunch, the pork bulgogi was tender and the sauce was sweet instead of spicy. Definitely a flavorful dish to try out.For beverage, I ordered the Rubus tea. It is very fruity drink topped with a small slice of orange and canned cherries. Price wise it is considered decent and will definitely try out the other chain. :)Tried the chef guksoo a week later at the same chain and wasn't impressive. I still prefer the Bibim Guksoo. The citrus drink was pretty decent too.

Constantly finding a place to drink a cup of coffee while relaxing, I went to The Marshmallow Tree. Situated in a HDB block below Telok Blangah, this place is well-decorated with different types of seatings and to the young at heart. Initially I thought the Bandung Latte was a caffeinated drink, until the server told me it wasn't. Still, this was a very nice drink. With the correct amount of steamed milk, vanilla and rose syrup added, it feels sweet and milky enough. The only downside to this is that I felt that it was rather pricey. The Macaron S'mores is also something unique to order here. The smores, which is essentially a marshmallow in between 2 macaron shells and smothered with the sauce of your liking (I chose Nutella). The smores burst upon the first mouthful. The marshmallows were soft and the Nutella made it feel more enriching. The shells were rather hard to chew on though. If you live nearby Telok Blangah, why not give this place a visit? I will find myself being here if I'm around the area again (I feel like trying the waffles!)

Super small cafe, not advisable for a large group. Nothing much to choose from the menu too. Salad sauce too sour for me. But like the complimentary marshmallow for each drink ordered.Slow service too but hope you enjoy taking photos of the nice garden decor.
